unnormalised: New Delhi: Concerns are mounting over the rising costs of construction materials in the Delhi-NCR region. A recent report by the Construction Material Price Index (CMPI) indicates a significant surge in the prices of essential building materials over the past quarter. Steel, a key component, has reportedly increased by 15% since 01/07/2024, reaching approximately Rs. 65,000 per tonne. This spike is attributed to increased demand and supply chain disruptions.
normalised: New Delhi: Concerns are mounting over the rising costs of construction materials in the Delhi-N-C-R region. A recent report by the Construction Material Price Index (C-M-P-I) indicates a significant surge in the prices of essential building materials over the past quarter. Steel, a key component, has reportedly increased by fifteen percent since first july two thousand and twenty four, reaching approximately rupee sixty five thousand per tonne. This spike is attributed to increased demand and supply chain disruptions.

unnormalised: Cement prices have also seen an uptick, with a 50 kg bag now costing around Rs. 400, up from Rs. 350 just three months ago. Industry experts attribute this rise to increased fuel costs and transportation challenges. The price of aggregates, measured in cubic meters (m3), has gone up by approximately 10%, currently standing at Rs. 1800/m3.
normalised: Cement prices have also seen an uptick, with a fifty kilogram bag now costing around rupee four hundred, up from rupee three hundred and fifty just three months ago. Industry experts attribute this rise to increased fuel costs and transportation challenges. The price of aggregates, measured in cubic meters (cubic meter), has gone up by approximately ten percent, currently standing at rupee one thousand eight hundred per cubic meter.

unnormalised: Labour costs, another critical factor in construction, have also increased. Daily wages for skilled labourers have risen from Rs. 700 to Rs. 850, reflecting the growing demand for construction workers in the booming real estate market. This rise, coupled with the increased cost of materials, is putting pressure on developers and contractors.
normalised: Labour costs, another critical factor in construction, have also increased. Daily wages for skilled labourers have risen from rupee seven hundred to rupee eight hundred and fifty, reflecting the growing demand for construction workers in the booming real estate market. This rise, coupled with the increased cost of materials, is putting pressure on developers and contractors.

unnormalised: The increase in material costs will likely have a cascading effect on the real estate sector, potentially leading to higher property prices and delays in project completion. The cost of constructing a standard 2BHK flat, measuring approximately 800 sq ft, is estimated to have increased by 8-10%. Smaller contractors and individual home builders are particularly vulnerable to these price fluctuations.
normalised: The increase in material costs will likely have a cascading effect on the real estate sector, potentially leading to higher property prices and delays in project completion. The cost of constructing a standard two B-H-K flat, measuring approximately eight hundred square feet, is estimated to have increased by eight to ten percent. Smaller contractors and individual home builders are particularly vulnerable to these price fluctuations.

unnormalised: Industry associations are urging the government to intervene and implement measures to stabilize material prices. Suggestions include easing supply chain bottlenecks and reducing taxes on essential construction materials. The long-term impact on the construction sector remains uncertain, but stakeholders are closely monitoring the situation.
